episodes.title: The Long View of Rising Sun

episodes.description: In this episode of The Long View, I'm pleased to be joined once again by Jim Shaw, as we continue our episode about Dominion. episodes.description: In this special episode of The Long View, I'm thrilled to be joined by both Joel Eddy and TC Petty III as we dive into and explore dice games! What makes them so popular in board game design nowadays? What was the inspiration behind the design of TC's VivaJava: The Coffee Game: The Dice Game? episodes.title: The Long View: Game of Thrones

Is this the modern Diplomacy? What are the differences between the first and second editions? Do you hold your friends close, but your enemies closer? Does a knowledge of the books and HBO series enhance the game or disrupt it? All these questions and more are answered in this episode of The Long View. As a bonus, Jens and Petur review the old classic game of Intrigue. A game of deceit, lies and backstabbing. Sense a pattern here? Check out the review! Finally, I review two new games. Is this a gateway worker placement game, or a themeless recipe filling drudge fest? Does the game stand up to repeated play? episodes.title: The Long View: Space Alert

episodes.title: The Long View: Difficult Themes and The Battle of the Five Armies
episodes.description: In this special episode of The Long View, I'm very happy to be joined once again by Joel Eddy, as we discuss how designers present difficult themes in board games. Which games deal with sensitive subjects well? Which miss the mark? Which, maybe, should not have been attempted? Are there any noticeable trends? All this and more is discussed in this episode of The Long View. As a bonus, I give a review of the new thematic game, The Battle of Five Armies. How is this different from War of the Ring (second edition)? What does it share in common? Is there room for both in your collection? Listen and find out! episodes.title: The Long View: Republic of Rome
episodes.description: In this episode of The Long View, I'm very pleased to be joined, all the way from Poland, by Adam Ceti as we discuss the old Avalon Hill classic, The Republic of Rome. Join us as we discuss why this title is so memorable, and why you should consider giving it a look. From the intense negotiations of the Senate phase, to the back room dealings and backstabbing, to the desperate struggle to win the battles and wars that always seem to be around the corner, this game is one that offers many unique experiences. Along the way we briefly compare this title to other classic negotiation games such as Diplomacy and Tammany Hall, and discuss the solo game options along with some of Adam's favorite optional rules. Is this old title a game for you? Listen and see for yourself! As a bonus, I also offer a review of two titles. First up is Fire in the Lake from GMT games at the 1:32:10 mark of the episode, and then a review of the recent hotness Splendor at the 2:07:13 mark of the episode. Is Fire in the Lake the best of the COIN Series? Does it evoke the feel and history of the conflict? Will it make your head explode as if you were an extra from the film Scanners? Was Splendor robbed of its rightful title of game of the year? Is there strategy lurking under the surface of this family game? Find out in these reviews from The Long View. If you enjoy the episode, please consider joining The Long View Guild, or follow us on twitter, iTunes, or Stitcher. Thanks to my sponsor, www.gamesurplus.com, thanks to The Dice Tower Network, and thanks, of course, to YOU for listening!

episodes.title: Game Design and Greenland with Phil Eklund and Philipp Klarmann
episodes.description: In this special episode of The Long View, I'm pleased to be joined by designers Phil Eklund and Philipp Klarmann as we discuss game design, and the upcoming game of Greenland. In the episode we discuss what makes Mr. Eklund's earlier designs and this new title so unique, the value of collaboration, the difference between a game and a simulation, and the role of education in game design. Along the way, "the Phils" tease us with some glimpses of even more new designs! As a bonus, I also review two new titles. The first is an outrageously fun new game from Eagle Gryphon titled Lords and Ladies, and then I discuss the fascinating mash-up of Chess and Deckbuilding found in For the Crown (Second edition) from Victory Point Games. The Lords and Ladies review can be found at the 1:45:00 mark of the episode, and the For the Crown review can be found at the 2:01:06 mark of the episode. As a note, we discuss the game of Greenland quite a bit, but never dive into the game itself in great detail, the focus is squarely on the design process and decisions made during the making of the game. If you would like a more complete picture of the game before or after you listen, please go the the Greenland game page and check out the video I made with W. Eric Martin at Gen Con, or listen to my review of the game in the Gen Con episode which you can find here in the BGG database, or at the podcast webpage of www.thelongviewpodcast.com Thanks, as always, to my sponsor www.gamesurplus.com, The Dice Tower and, of course, thanks to YOU for listening!

episodes.title: The Long View: War of the Ring

episodes.title: The Long View: Through the Ages
